<ce:caption id="cap0010">
<ce:simple-para id="fspara0010" view="all">(a) Coordination environment about metal cation (M = Ni, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; Co, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: (A) x, - y + 1, z - 1/2; (B) – x + 3/2, y + 1/2, - z + 3/2; (C) x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2. (b) A drawing showing the dinuclear unit. (c) A drawing showing the 3D coordination network. (d) A drawing with the (3,5)-conneted {4,6,8}{4,6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>,8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>} topology. (e) A drawing wiyh the 8-conected (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)-8T2 topology.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="alttext0020" role="short">Fig. 1</ce:alt-text>

</ce:figure>

(c) A drawing showing the 3D coordination network. (d) A drawing with the (3,5)-conneted {4,6,8}{4,64,85} topology. (e) A drawing wiyh the 8-conected (424.64)-8T2 topology.  Fig. 1

<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0025">
<ce:simple-para id="fspara0025" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Co(II) ion in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: (A) x, y −1, z; (B) -x, y - 2, -z + 1/2. (b) The quadruple-strained 1D helical chain. (c) The coordination mode of the 2,4-PDC<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligand. (d) The 1D rectangular nanotubes are supported by extensive N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>--O hydrogen bonds to the carbonyl oxygen atoms (blue dashed lines) and carboxylate oxygen atoms (green dashed lines) as well as O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>--O hydrogen bonds (pink dashed lines). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) Coordination environment of Co(II) ion in 5. Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: (A) x, y -1, z; (B) -x, y - 2, -z + 1/2. (b) The quadruple-strained 1D helical chain. (c) The coordination mode of the 2,4-PDC2- ligand. (d) The 1D rectangular nanotubes are supported by extensive NH--O hydrogen bonds to the carbonyl oxygen atoms (blue dashed lines) and carboxylate oxygen atoms (green dashed lines) as well as OH--O hydrogen bonds (pink dashed lines). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)  Fig. 4

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">The syntheses, structures and thermal properties of six coordination polymers based on semi-rigid <ce:italic>N,N′</ce:italic>-bis(3-pyridinyl)terephthalamide (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>), flexible <ce:italic>N,N′</ce:italic>-di(3-pyridyl)adipoamide (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>) and <ce:italic>N,N′</ce:italic>-di(3-pyridyl)suberoamide (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>) and auxiliary dicarboxylate ligands, [M(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>)(AIPA)·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>, (M = Ni, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; Co, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>AIPA = 5-acetamido isophthalic acid), [Ni(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>)(AIPA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, [Co(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(AIPA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, [Co(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>)(2,4-PDC)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (2,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PDC = 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid), <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, and [Co(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>)(5-Br-IPA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (5-Br<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>IPA = 5-bromoisophthalic acid), <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, are reported, which have been structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are isomorphous, forming 3D nets with the new (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>⋅8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) topology, which can be further simplified as self-catenated networks with the (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)-8T2 topology, while <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 1D looped chain and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> show 2D layers with the (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>⋅8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>⋅6)-3,4L83 and (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>sql</ce:bold> topologies, respectively. Moreover, complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> shows quadruple-strained helices formed by cobalt ions and <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands, which are supported by 2,4-PDC<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anions to construct the rare single-walled metal-organic nanotubes that are supported by extensive N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>--O and O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>--O hydrogen bonds. The roles of ligand flexibility and the identity of the metal ion in the formation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> as well as their thermal properties are discussed.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The syntheses, structures and thermal properties of six coordination polymers based on semi-rigid N,N'-bis(3-pyridinyl)terephthalamide (L  1 ), flexible N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)adipoamide (L  2 ) and N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)suberoamide (L  3 ) and auxiliary dicarboxylate ligands, [M(L  1 )(AIPA)⋅2H2O]n, (M=Ni, 1; Co, 2; H2AIPA=5-acetamido isophthalic acid), [Ni(L  2 )(AIPA)(H2O)2]n, 3, [Co(L  2 )0.5(AIPA)(H2O)]n, 4, [Co(L  3 )(2,4-PDC)(H2O)]n (2,4-H2PDC=2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid), 5, and [Co(L  3 )(5-Br-IPA)(H2O)]n (5-BrH2IPA=5-bromoisophthalic acid), 6, are reported, which have been structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. Complexes 1 and 2 are isomorphous, forming 3D nets with the new (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅64⋅85) topology, which can be further simplified as self-catenated networks with the (424⋅64)-8T2 topology, while 3 is a 1D looped chain and 4 and 6 show 2D layers with the (42⋅63⋅8)(42⋅6)-3,4L83 and (44⋅62)-sql topologies, respectively. Moreover, complex 5 shows quadruple-strained helices formed by cobalt ions and L  3  ligands, which are supported by 2,4-PDC2- anions to construct the rare single-walled metal-organic nanotubes that are supported by extensive NH--O and OH--O hydrogen bonds. The roles of ligand flexibility and the identity of the metal ion in the formation of 1-6 as well as their thermal properties are discussed.

elements.clean_text:
Six coordination polymers based on bis-pyridyl-bis-amide and polycarboxylate ligands are reported.

The effects of flexibility and coordination mode of the ligands on the structural types are examined.

Formation of quadruple-strained and single-walled nanotubular frameworks is also discussed.

The role of the metal center in the structural diversity is susceptible to the change of the flexibility of the bpba ligands.

Introduction

There has been growing interest in the designed synthesis of novel coordination polymers (CPs) during recent years, not only due to their potential applications in many areas such as magnetism, luminescence, catalysis and gas storage but also their intriguing structures and diverse topologies []. Judicial choice of metal-ion template and spacer ligand may form CPs with well-defined networks. Despite the fact that diverse bis-pyridyl-bis-amide (bpba) ligands-based CPs with fascinating structures have been reported, the control of structural dimensionality remains a challenge and the factors that govern the structural diversity are less ascertained []. Much more work is thus required to illuminate this phenomenon.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The preparation of CPs with helical structures to mimic the biological helices has been the subject of extensive investigation []. Our recent study has indicated that halide anions have significant effect on folding and unfolding of the Zn(II) double-stranded helical CPs containing the <ce:italic>N,N′</ce:italic>-di(4-pyridyl)adipoamide ligands []. We have also shown that reactions of the flexible <ce:italic>N,N′</ce:italic>-di(3-pyridyl)dodecanediamide with Zn(II) and Cd(II) metal salts in the presence of different polycarboxylic acids afforded CPs which manifest the quintuple and double helices []. Recently, we have reported that the 1D zigzag and single-strained helical HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> CPs containing flexible 2,2’-(1,2-phenylene)-bis(N-pyridin-3-yl)acetamide exhibited reversible structural transformation triggered by solvent exchange []. Obviously, by manipulating the flexibility of the bpba ligand, single to multiple-strained helical CPs can be achieved.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The preparation of CPs with helical structures to mimic the biological helices has been the subject of extensive investigation []. Our recent study has indicated that halide anions have significant effect on folding and unfolding of the Zn(II) double-stranded helical CPs containing the N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)adipoamide ligands []. We have also shown that reactions of the flexible N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)dodecanediamide with Zn(II) and Cd(II) metal salts in the presence of different polycarboxylic acids afforded CPs which manifest the quintuple and double helices []. Recently, we have reported that the 1D zigzag and single-strained helical HgI2 CPs containing flexible 2,2'-(1,2-phenylene)-bis(N-pyridin-3-yl)acetamide exhibited reversible structural transformation triggered by solvent exchange []. Obviously, by manipulating the flexibility of the bpba ligand, single to multiple-strained helical CPs can be achieved.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">General procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">IR spectra (KBr disk) were obtained from a JASCO FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Elemental analyses were achieved from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer or an elementar VarioEL-III analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) measurements were carried out on a TG/DTA 6200 analyzer of SII Nano Technology Inc., or a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 analyzer over the temperature range of 30–1000 °C (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and 30–600 °C (for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) at a heating rate of 10 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under a nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction instrument were performed on a Bruker D2 PHASER diffractometer with a CuK<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> (λ<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> = 1.54 Å) radiation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

IR spectra (KBr disk) were obtained from a JASCO FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Elemental analyses were achieved from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer or an elementar VarioEL-III analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) measurements were carried out on a TG/DTA 6200 analyzer of SII Nano Technology Inc., or a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 analyzer over the temperature range of 30-1000°C (for 1-5) and 30-600°C (for 6) at a heating rate of 10°C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction instrument were performed on a Bruker D2 PHASER diffractometer with a CuKα (λα=1.54Å) radiation.

The reagent Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O was purchased from J. T. Baker Co., Ni(OAc)2⋅4H2O from Alfa Aesar and 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,4-H2PDC) from Aldrich Chemical Co. The ligands 5-acetamido isophthalic acid (H2AIPA) [], 5-bromoisophthalic acid (5-BrH2IPA) [], N,N'-bis(3-pyridinyl)terephthalamide (L  1 ), N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)adipoamide (L  2 ) and N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)suberoamide (L  3 ) were prepared according to published procedures [].

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The single crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes <ce:bold>1–6</ce:bold> were collected on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer at 298 K, which was equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo K<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> (λ<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> = 0.71073 Å) radiation []. Data reduction was performed by using standard methods with well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization corrections. An empirical absorption correction based on “multi-scan” was applied to the data. The position of some of the heavier atoms were located by the direct or Patterson method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-square refinements, while the hydrogen atoms were added by using the HADD command in SHELXTL 6.1012 []. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The single crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1-6 were collected on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer at 298K, which was equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λα=0.71073Å) radiation []. Data reduction was performed by using standard methods with well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization corrections. An empirical absorption correction based on "multi-scan" was applied to the data. The position of some of the heavier atoms were located by the direct or Patterson method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-square refinements, while the hydrogen atoms were added by using the HADD command in SHELXTL 6.1012 []. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

Structures of 1 and 2 

Crystals of 1 and 2 are isomorphous, which conform to the monoclinic space group C2/c with one M(Ⅱ) (M=Ni, 1; Co, 2) cation, one L  1  ligand, one AIPA2- ligand and two cocrystallized water molecules in the asymmetric unit.  (a) depicts a representative drawing showing the coordination environment about the M(Ⅱ) metal center, which is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L  1  ligands [M-N=2.108(2) and 2.117(2) Å for 1; 2.168(2) and 2.178(2) Å for 2] and four oxygen atoms from two AIPA2- ligands [M-O=1.982(1) - 2.194(1) Å for 1; 1.992(2) - 2.268(1) Å for 2]. The metal atoms are linked by the AIPA2- ligands that adopt the μ 3-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1 coordination mode to form to afford 2D layers with M2(μ-COO)2 dimeric units, (b), which are further extended by the L  1  ligands to form a 3D framework, (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0095" view="all">If the metal ions are defined as 5-coordinated nodes and the AIPA<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands as 3-coordinated nodes, topological analysis reveals that the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be regarded as a 3,5-coordinated net with the new (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>⋅8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) topology, (d), as determined using TOPOS []. Moreover, If the M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> dimeric units are taken as structural building units SBU and defined as nodes, the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be further simplified as a 8-coordinated net with a rare self-catenated (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)-8T2 topology, (e). The self-catenation could be shown as cross-linking of the 2D 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-sql nets pillared by rods and each shortest four-membered ring is catenated by one rod of the same network.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: If the metal ions are defined as 5-coordinated nodes and the AIPA2- ligands as 3-coordinated nodes, topological analysis reveals that the structures of 1 and 2 can be regarded as a 3,5-coordinated net with the new (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅64⋅85) topology, (d), as determined using TOPOS []. Moreover, If the M2(μ-COO)2 dimeric units are taken as structural building units SBU and defined as nodes, the structures of 1 and 2 can be further simplified as a 8-coordinated net with a rare self-catenated (424⋅64)-8T2 topology, (e). The self-catenation could be shown as cross-linking of the 2D 44-sql nets pillared by rods and each shortest four-membered ring is catenated by one rod of the same network.

Structure of 4 

Crystals of 4 conforms to the triclinic space group Pī with one Co(II) cation, a half of L  2  ligand, one AIPA2- ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit.  (a) shows the coordination environment about the Co(II) metal centers, which is six-coordinated by one pyridyl nitrogen atom from the L  2  ligand [NiN=2.140(1) Å], four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three AIPA2- ligands [NiO=2.010(1) - 2.194(1) Å] and one coordinated water molecule [NiO=2.168(1) Å]. The AIPA2- ligands adopt the μ 3-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1 coordination mode, linking the Co(II) ions to form 1D looped chains with dinuclear units, (b), which are further connected by the L  2  ligands through the two pyridyl nitrogen atoms to form pleated 2D layers with loops, (c). If the Co(II) cations are defined as 4-connected node, and the AIPA2- ligands as the 3-connected nodes while the L  2  ligands as linkers, the structure of complex 4 can be regarded as a 3,4-binodal net with the (42⋅63⋅8)(42⋅6)-3,4L83 topology, (d).

<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">A comparison of the structures in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveals that the ligand flexibility is important in determining the structural diversity of the bpba-based Ni(II) and Co(II) CPs. While the semi-rigid <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> induce the formation of the 3D self-catenated frameworks with the (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)-8T2 topology, the involvement of the flexible <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands results in a 1D looped chain and a 2D layer with the (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>⋅8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>⋅6)-3,4L83 topology for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively. Besides, the role of the metal center in the structural diversity is susceptible to the change of the ligand flexibility. While the metal identity plays no significant role in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> containing the semi-rigid <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands, the Ni(II) and Co(II) ions are important in determining the structures of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> involving the flexible <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A comparison of the structures in 1-4 reveals that the ligand flexibility is important in determining the structural diversity of the bpba-based Ni(II) and Co(II) CPs. While the semi-rigid L  1  ligands in 1 and 2 induce the formation of the 3D self-catenated frameworks with the (424⋅64)-8T2 topology, the involvement of the flexible L  2  ligands results in a 1D looped chain and a 2D layer with the (42⋅63⋅8)(42⋅6)-3,4L83 topology for 3 and 4, respectively. Besides, the role of the metal center in the structural diversity is susceptible to the change of the ligand flexibility. While the metal identity plays no significant role in complexes 1 and 2 containing the semi-rigid L  1  ligands, the Ni(II) and Co(II) ions are important in determining the structures of 3 and 4 involving the flexible L  2  ligands.

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>(a) shows the coordination environment about Co(II) metal center, which is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands [Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N = 2.118(2) and 2.152(2) Å], one nitrogeon [Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N = 2.138(2) Å] and two oxygen atoms [Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O = 2.084(1) and 2.114(1) Å] from two 2,4-PDC<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligands and one oxygen atom from the water molecule [Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O = 2.115(2) Å], resulting in a disorted octahedral geometry. By the linkage of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands, the Co atoms are strung into a 1D 2-fold [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> helix with a pitch of 23.91 Å. Most interestingly, the long hexamethylene backbones of the <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> ligands that adopt the near-orthogonal arrangement allow the interleaving of three other helices, resulting in a fascinating quadruple-strained helix within the structure of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, (b). The quadruple-strained helix is supported by two linear chains formed by the 2,4-PDC<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligands, which chelate and bridge the Co(II) ions through the pyridyl nitrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms of the adjacent carboxylate groups, (c), leaving the oxygen atoms of the other carboxylate groups non-coordinated and forming 1D single-walled nanotubular frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of 5 

Crystals of 5 conform to the monoclinic space group C2/c with one Co(II) ion, one L  3  ligand, one 2,4-PDC2- ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit.  (a) shows the coordination environment about Co(II) metal center, which is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L  3  ligands [CoN=2.118(2) and 2.152(2) Å], one nitrogeon [CoN=2.138(2) Å] and two oxygen atoms [CoO=2.084(1) and 2.114(1) Å] from two 2,4-PDC2- ligands and one oxygen atom from the water molecule [CoO=2.115(2) Å], resulting in a disorted octahedral geometry. By the linkage of L  3  ligands, the Co atoms are strung into a 1D 2-fold [CoL  3 ]n helix with a pitch of 23.91Å. Most interestingly, the long hexamethylene backbones of the L  3  ligands that adopt the near-orthogonal arrangement allow the interleaving of three other helices, resulting in a fascinating quadruple-strained helix within the structure of 5, (b). The quadruple-strained helix is supported by two linear chains formed by the 2,4-PDC2- ligands, which chelate and bridge the Co(II) ions through the pyridyl nitrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms of the adjacent carboxylate groups, (c), leaving the oxygen atoms of the other carboxylate groups non-coordinated and forming 1D single-walled nanotubular frameworks.

<ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The single-walled nanotubular framework with quadruple-strained helices of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> significantly contrasts with the quintuple-strained helical structure of [Zn(2,4-PDC)(L)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (L = <ce:italic>N,N′</ce:italic>-di(3-pyridyl)dodecanediamide; 2,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PDC = 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) [], which indicate the length of the spacer ligand (L with decamethylene backbone vs <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> with hexamethylene backbone) and thus the flexibility may determine the number of the helices. Moreover, the formation of single-walled nanotubular frameworks with multiple-strained helices within the structures of these two complexes can be ascribed to the structure-directing role of the 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylate that adopt both the chelating and bridging bonding modes through the pyridyl nitrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms of the adjacent carboxylate groups. The discrete nanotubes of complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> that display quadruple-strained helices represent a new family of single walled metal-organic nanotubes (SWMONTs) [,] that are supported by the polycarboxylate ligands.</ce:para>

Moreover, the formation of single-walled nanotubular frameworks with multiple-strained helices within the structures of these two complexes can be ascribed to the structure-directing role of the 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylate that adopt both the chelating and bridging bonding modes through the pyridyl nitrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms of the adjacent carboxylate groups. The discrete nanotubes of complex 5 that display quadruple-strained helices represent a new family of single walled metal-organic nanotubes (SWMONTs) [,] that are supported by the polycarboxylate ligands.

elements.clean_text:
Structure of 6 

Crystals of 6 conforms to the monoclinic space group Pī with one Co(II) ion, one L  3  ligand, one 5-Br-IPA2- ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit.  (a) shows the coordination environment about Co(II) metal center, which is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L  3  ligands [CoN=2.142(2) and 2.165(2) Å], three oxygen atoms from two 5-Br-IPA2- ligands [CoO=2.023(2) - 2.170(2) Å] and one oxygen atom from the water molecule [CoO=2.074(2) Å]. The Co(II) cations are linked by the 5-Br-IPA2- ligands that adopts a μ2-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ0 coordination mode and further connected by L  3  ligands to form a 2D layer, (b). Topologically, each Co(II) atom acts as four-connected node, while the L  3  and 5-Br-IPA2- serve as linkers, and the structure of 6 displays the (44.62)-sql topology, (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0135" view="all">A structural comparison of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> reveals that the 2,4-PDC<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and 5-Br-IPA<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligands dictate the structural arrangements, resulting in a 1D single-walled nanotube with quadruple-strained helices and a 2D layer, respectively. The structural difference in complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> demonstrates that judicial choice of the polycarboxylate ligand is important in controlling the folding and unfolding of the helical structures.</ce:para>

The structural difference in complexes 5 and 6 demonstrates that judicial choice of the polycarboxylate ligand is important in controlling the folding and unfolding of the helical structures.

Ligand conformation

The ligand conformation in bpba with flexible -(CH2)n-skeleton has been proposed as followed: (1) The CCCC torsion angles (θ) determine ‘anti' (A) and ‘gauche' (G) conformations if 180≥θ>90° and 0≤θ≤90° respectively. (2) The orientation of CO or NH group defines ‘cis' and ‘trans' either two same groups are on the same direction or on the opposite direction. (3) Considering two pairs of amide and pyridyl ring, three more conformations syn-syn, anti-anti and syn-anti are specified depending on the orientations of pyridyl nitrogen atom and amide oxygen atom. Base on this descriptor, the L  1  without the flexible -(CH2)n-skeleton in 1 and 2 adopt the trans anti-anti conformation, while the L  2  in 3 and 4 the GAA-cis syn-syn and AAA-trans anti-anti conformations and the L  3  in 5 and 6 the AAAAA-trans syn-anti and GAAAA-cis anti-syn conformations, respectively.   lists the ligand conformations, coordination modes and structures of complexes 1-6. It can be shown that the L  2  and L  3  ligands are sufficiently flexible to implement the stereochemical requirements for their corresponding structural types.

elements.clean_text:
.Thermal properties

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of complexes 1-6 were conducted in a nitrogen atmosphere,   and . The TGA curve of 1 shows the gradual weight loss of two water molecules (calculated 5.67%, observed 5.84%) in 30-200°C and the weight loss of 63.08% (calculated 60.25%) in 350-1000°C corresponds to the decomposition of L  1  and AIPA2- ligands, while those for 2 occurred in 30-180°C (calculated 5.67%, observed 5.85%) and 350-1000°C (calculated 59.92%, observed 61.67%), respectively. The TGA curve of 3 displays the gradual weight loss of water molecules (calculated 5.87%, observed 4.98%) in 30-250°C and the decomposition of the L  2  and AIPA2- ligands with a weight loss of 78.41% (calculated 84.58%) in 300-1000°C. While the TGA curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 68.90% (calculated 66.09%) in 200-1000°C, which can be ascribed to the removal of the L  2  and AIPA2- ligands, that of 5 shows the gradual weight loss of the water molecules (calculated 3.17%, observed 3.15%) in 30-250°C and another weight loss of 86.72% (calculated 83.04%) in 250-900° C, corresponding to the decomposition of L  3  and 2,4-PDC2- ligands. The TGA curve of 6 shows the gradual weight loss of water molecules (calculated 2.75%, observed 3.00%) in 30-220°C and the weight loss of 85.60% (calculated 87.01%) in 220-600°C corresponds to the decomposition of L  3  and 5-Br-IPA2- ligands. It can be shown that the removal of the ligands of complexes 1 and 2 started at higher temperature of 350°C as compared with the other complexes, presumably due to their durable 3D frameworks.

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0125">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">The syntheses, structures and thermal properties of six CPs constructed from the semi-rigid <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:sup>, the flexible <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> and <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> and the polycarboxylic acids have been successfully accomplished. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are isomorphous, forming 3D nets with the new (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>⋅8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) topology, which can be further simplified as self-catenated networks with the (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)-8T2 topology, while <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 1D looped chain and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> shows 2D layers with the (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>⋅8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>⋅6)-3,4L83 and (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>⋅6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>sql</ce:bold> topologies, respectively. Moreover, complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> forms single-walled nanotubular frameworks with quadruple-strained helices that are interlinked through extensive N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>--O and O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>--O hydrogen bonds. The structural differences in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveals that the role of the metal center in the structural diversity is susceptible to the change of the flexibility of the bpba ligands. We have shown that judicial choice of the bpba and polycarboxylate ligands is important in determining the number of helices of the multiple-strained helical CPs and in controlling the folding and unfolding of the helical structures, which are analogous to the DNA structure in terms of topology. While the formation of single-walled nanotubular frameworks with multiple-strained helices can be ascribed to the structure-directing role of the 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylate ligands, the different number of the helices is due to the different flexibility of the bpba ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The syntheses, structures and thermal properties of six CPs constructed from the semi-rigid L  1 , the flexible L  2  and L  3  and the polycarboxylic acids have been successfully accomplished. Complexes 1 and 2 are isomorphous, forming 3D nets with the new (4⋅6⋅8)(4⋅64⋅85) topology, which can be further simplified as self-catenated networks with the (424⋅64)-8T2 topology, while 3 is a 1D looped chain and 4 and 6 shows 2D layers with the (42⋅63⋅8)(42⋅6)-3,4L83 and (44⋅62)-sql topologies, respectively. Moreover, complex 5 forms single-walled nanotubular frameworks with quadruple-strained helices that are interlinked through extensive NH--O and OH--O hydrogen bonds. The structural differences in 1-4 reveals that the role of the metal center in the structural diversity is susceptible to the change of the flexibility of the bpba ligands. We have shown that judicial choice of the bpba and polycarboxylate ligands is important in determining the number of helices of the multiple-strained helical CPs and in controlling the folding and unfolding of the helical structures, which are analogous to the DNA structure in terms of topology. While the formation of single-walled nanotubular frameworks with multiple-strained helices can be ascribed to the structure-directing role of the 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylate ligands, the different number of the helices is due to the different flexibility of the bpba ligands.

cln_elements.clean_text:
.Thermal properties

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of complexes 1-6 were conducted in a nitrogen atmosphere,   and . The TGA curve of 1 shows the gradual weight loss of two water molecules (calculated 5.67%, observed 5.84%) in 30-200°C and the weight loss of 63.08% (calculated 60.25%) in 350-1000°C corresponds to the decomposition of L  1  and AIPA2- ligands, while those for 2 occurred in 30-180°C (calculated 5.67%, observed 5.85%) and 350-1000°C (calculated 59.92%, observed 61.67%), respectively. The TGA curve of 3 displays the gradual weight loss of water molecules (calculated 5.87%, observed 4.98%) in 30-250°C and the decomposition of the L  2  and AIPA2- ligands with a weight loss of 78.41% (calculated 84.58%) in 300-1000°C. While the TGA curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 68.90% (calculated 66.09%) in 200-1000°C, which can be ascribed to the removal of the L  2  and AIPA2- ligands, that of 5 shows the gradual weight loss of the water molecules (calculated 3.17%, observed 3.15%) in 30-250°C and another weight loss of 86.72% (calculated 83.04%) in 250-900° C, corresponding to the decomposition of L  3  and 2,4-PDC2- ligands. The TGA curve of 6 shows the gradual weight loss of water molecules (calculated 2.75%, observed 3.00%) in 30-220°C and the weight loss of 85.60% (calculated 87.01%) in 220-600°C corresponds to the decomposition of L  3  and 5-Br-IPA2- ligands. It can be shown that the removal of the ligands of complexes 1 and 2 started at higher temperature of 350°C as compared with the other complexes, presumably due to their durable 3D frameworks.
